BUSINESS CONFIDENTIAL

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

FLEXIBLE FOAM PRODUCTS, INC.
501 INDUSTRIAL BLVD.
TERRELL, TEXAS 75160

Flexible Foam, Inc. owns and operates a polyurethane foam manufacturing facility on 501 Industrial Boulvard.  Flexible Foam receives raw materials at its facility, mixes the materials to produce a polyurethane foam bun on a foam production line.  The foam is then cured and stored on site prior to shipping to customers.  Some limited fabrication takes place at the facility.  

One of the components used in the production of polyurethane foam is toluene diisocyanate (TDI).  This compound is subject to EPA?s Risk Management Rule.

Toluene diisocyanate is delivered to the 501 Industrial Boulvard facility in tank trucks.  The trucks are off-loaded to a storage tank located inside the building.  Because the storage of TDI takes place inside the building,  the probability of release of toluene diisocyante vapors into the atmosphere is reduced.  As a result, the impact of such a release on the surrounding community is minimized.  There are no inhabited receptors (buildings and people other than the Flexible facility) that would be impacted by the release of stored or unloaded toluene diisocyanate but undeveloped property beyond the property line to the East and South would be impacted by a worst-case scenario..  

Because there are public receptors (undeveloped) and there have been no significant incidents of release in the last five years, Flexible Foam, 501 Industrial Boulevard facility is classified as a "Program 2" facility.

At the Flexible Products, Inc. ( Flexible Foam) plant in Terrell, Texas, we handle toluene diisocyanate (TDI), which is considered hazardous and is regulated by the EPA.  The same properties that make TDI valuable for use at our facility also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in the handling of the substance.  TDI is considered a toxic substanc

e, and associated safety precautions have been implemented to (1) prevent unnecessary human exposure, (2) reduce the threat to the health of our employees at the Nu-Foam Chattanooga plant, and (3) reduce the threat to nearby members of our community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.

We are committed to the safety of our employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Successful implementation of our accidental release prevention program will help ensure that emergencies are unlikely and reduce the likelihood that emergency response procedures will be needed.  Nevertheless, an emergency such as a release of TDI is possible.  We have emergency response procedures to help ensure that accidents will be mitigated properly without undue risk to the public, environment, employees, contractors, or other personnel within the plant.

Description of the facility and the regulated substances handled

The primary purpose of this facility is to produce polyurethane foam, which is sold to other facilities and is used to produce furniture, bedding, carpet padding and a number of other products.  TDI is one of the reactants required to produce our polyurethane foam.  TDI is received by railcar and by tank truck, and is stored in two indoor storage tanks.  The maximum quantity of TDI stored in the process (i.e., in storage tanks and in up to two standby railcars) at our plant is about 200,000 lb.  The TDI is piped to a mix head where it is mixed with other reactants to produce a slab of polyurethane foam.  The foam products are shipped to customers by truck.

TDI is the only substance handled at our plant that is regulated by EPA?s risk management program (RMP) rule.  This substance is covered because the maximum quantity contained in our TDI process exceeds EPA?s threshold quantity of 10,000 lb for TDI.

Offsite consequence analysis of

release scenarios

We performed an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release to affect the public or the environment.  The OCA consists of evaluating worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios (ARS's).  We do not expect a worst-case release scenario to ever occur.  An ARS represents a release that might occur during the lifetime of a facility like ours.  ARS?s can help us to work with the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) to improve the community emergency response plan.

The main objective of performing the OCA is to determine the distance at which an accidental release might affect the public (the endpoint distance).  The following could occur at the endpoint distance: Most people at the endpoint distance of a toxic substance release like TDI would be able to walk away from the exposure without any long-term health consequences, although some short-term consequences (e.g., strong eye or throat irritation) are likely.  Some people who are particularly susceptible to the released substance could be incapacitated.

The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps

The plant has implemented programs and procedures that comply with EPA?s Level 2 Accidental Release Prevention Program Rule.  Our facility qualifies for Level 2 coverage because (1) our worst-case release scenario for TDI can impact persons across the property boundary of the nearest public receptor, (2) TDI is exempt from OSHA?s process safety management standard, and (3) our polyurethane foam process has not been targeted by the EPA for Level 3 coverage.  Our accidental release program is designed to systematically accomplish the following functions:

? Control the creation and retention of safety information regarding the regulated substances, processes, and equipment
 
? Conduct hazard reviews to identify, evaluate, and control process hazards associated with the regulated substances, processes, and procedures
 
? Create, maintain, and evaluate operating procedures for activities within or near processes that use regulated substances
 
? Provide training for personnel who operate covered processes so that they safely perform their jobs
 
? Monitor and control maintenance activities that can affect the mechanical integrity of equipment used in covered processes
 
? Confirm through compliance audits that RMP practices at the plant are consistent with our written programs and that the programs are adequate to address all of the requirements of the RMP rule
 
? Ensure that process incidents, particularly those of catastrophic magnitude or potential, are thoroughly investigate

d using our incident investigation procedures and that relevant findings are communicated throughout the plant to help prevent recurrence


 The TDI process at our plant has hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The prevention program outlined above is applied to the TDI process.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accidental releases that could be caused by equipment failures, human errors, and management system failures.
 
 In addition to the accidental release prevention program, our plant has safety features on many units to help (1) quickly detect a release, (2) contain or control a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of or mitigate a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various units of the TDI process:
 
? Release Detection 
 
? Process alarms (e.g., high level alarms and flow cutoff relays on the TDI storage tanks)
? Continuous operator surveillance (e.g., during TDI tanker unloading and TDI supply to the foam process)
 
? Release Containment/Control
 
? Curbing or dikes to contain TDI liquid releases
? TDI storage tanks located inside an enclosed building
? Automated shutdown systems for critical process parameters (e.g., high pressure)
? Pressure relief devices on equipment to prevent rupture
? Valves to permit isolation of process equipment
? TDI railcar inner tank surrounded by an outer shell filled with insulation
? Vapor displaced from storage tanks during unloading is vented through a carbon filter
? Facility personnel in attendance whenever TDI is being transferred from a bulk deliver 
  vessel to storage tanks.
 
? Release Mitigation
 
? Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
? Trained emergency response personnel
? Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing 
  apparatus)
 
 Five-year accident history
 
 We have had no releases of TDI in the last 5 years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property

damage on site, or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site.  We have had one small release of TDI inside the indoor contained tank room over the past 5 years.  That release was less than 100 lb of TDI and was quickly neutralized and remediated. The release was not large enough to result in injuries or significant damage and was exempt from reporting requirements due to the small quantity.
 
 Emergency response program
 
 Our emergency response program is based on the requirements in OSHA?s emergency action plan regulation, OSHA?s hazardous waste and emergency operations regulation, and EPA?s emergency response program requirements in its RMP rule.  Our program includes procedures for responding to a release of TDI.  Our procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary, based on modifications made to plant processes or other facilities, by using management of change procedures.  Personnel affected by changes in the program are informed and trained on those changes.
 
 The emergency response plan for the plant is coordinated with the LEPC.  This coordination includes providing them with a copy of the ERP and subsequent telephone call and invitation to tour the plant.  The plant has around-the-clock communications capability with the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations such as the fire department.  This provid

es a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  
 
 Planned changes to improve safety
 
 We strive to improve the safety of our TDI process through periodic safety reviews.  Our hazard review and incident investigation programs are especially designed to identify needed process safety improvements, some of which result in changes to the process.  The RMP is viewed as a living document and will be subject to revisions as appropriate, based on process changes and on-the-job evaluations of existing procedures, which will then be submitted to the Management Review Committee prior to implementation of recommended changes.  Specific plans implemented are containment for entire railcar contents and automatic cutoff system connected to storage tank high-level alarms.
 
 Past changes to improve safety

? Provided high-level alarm of the TDI and other feeds to prevent overfilling the TDI storage tanks
 
? Revised operating procedures to resolve findings from the latest TDI process hazard review.
